text: good morning and welcome uh we're going
to be talking about Agentic B how to get
AI agents to talk to Tetragonon and my
name is Himl i'm the co-founder and CTO
at Kenopus based in Sydney Australia the
land of kangaroos great beaches and
amazing coffee let's get started u so
recent developments in the AI are
reshaping the design patterns in
observability starting from high
fidelity data is becoming more critical
than ever because the accuracy of the AI
agents depend on the quality of the data
and that's where Tetragonon really
shines by providing us high fidelity for
golden signals of security observability
as close as possible to the event itself
the second AI agents can't really work
with raw data so we need to create
contextualized intelligence so they are
able to perform uh actions and are able
to understand the data the way humans do
finally the manual human-driven
dashboards um will be moving and
shifting towards agentic workflows and
that's going to move the whole
observability space from reactive to
proactive uh let's try to build out an
architecture so we're going to be using
Tetragonon to extract information on
processes file system access network uh
and use enforcement policies and we will
augment tetragonon with flow pulse
sensors to maintain its state on the
network traffic so we are not generating
a lot of events for every single packet
performing aggregations and talk to
tetragonon over the gRPC API to push
enforcement and dynamic tracing policies
so this forms our highfidelity data
layer followed by that we're going to
convert raw observability data into
asset evidences asset being containers
um or VMs um or we can call it workload
in the form of classification of the
container is it a web server is it is it
a database or is it external talking by
then baselining the behavior of the
containers uh looking at the data flow o
over the network what sort of data is
being exchanged and to where and then
classifying the runtime profile of the
container into anomalous and malicious
behavior and this feeds into building
out the workflows by the AI agents here
we're using the GPD 40 model as well as
the cloud set 3.0 to build out our
workflows so let's take a look at two
examples of the workflow and how we can
build that out
first one is the runtime vulnerability
prioritization so static vulnerabilities
don't really work very well because too
many false positives uh and not all of
them are actually exploitable in the
application and there are too many of
those could be hundreds so to solve this
problem um the way we approach it is we
first try to get the software bomb using
something like sift which will provide
you with all the file path that might be
in play in all the software packages and
binaries and then we're going to run
that through gripe to get a list of
vulnerabilities attached to those paths
and we can also check that against Kev
databases after getting that we're going
to feed back into Tetragonon some
dynamic tracing policies to track those
file paths being executed or dynamically
loaded uh by the processes and combining
this with the network data flow is going
to generate our behavioral evidence
chains in the form of JSON logs or
generated text by the LLM models the
workflow looks like this the agent crew
first generates the priority funnel
which brings the vulnerability through
critical how many are fixable how many
are running in privileged containers to
how many are exploitable in runtime that
reduces the vulnerability count
significantly then the agents would
assess the risk using data flows and
classification is that a container that
talks to a sensitive database or is an
external facing uh which can increase
the risk and then correlate previous
reports that have been generated to look
at if there are any updates or changes
that have happened in the application
and finally generates a report for every
container vulnerability that needs to be
actioned it takes around 1 to 2 minutes
for the agent crew to generate that
report and consumes around 30,000 to
60,000 tokens uh costing around 25 cents
per report which is pretty
good we'll have a look at a quick demo
in a moment but let's have a look at a
much more complicated workflow of
runtime thread detection
to achieve this we're going to be
forming an extensive baseline of all the
processes in um coming all the
information coming from Tetragonon in
the form of image baselining process
baselining network baselining asset
classifications and the data flows by
looking at the runtime behavioral
profile of all the containers we're
going to generate evidences in the form
of baseline deviations or um runtime
context in the form of unseen images
container deletes sensitive file
accesses host mounts or access to Linux
capabilities in a privileged container
all this forms again a part of our
behavioral evidence chain tied to every
container or an asset in the form of
JSON logs images and text so here we are
using image to describe the time series
behavior on on the network and also the
graph of what are the assets the
container is connected to so LLM models
are really good at uh reading the images
in a similar way humans do to detect
anomalies spikes and drops and to be
able to visualize what's really
happening without using complicated
anomalous detection
algorithms here the agentic workflow is
a little bit more sophisticated
comprising of three different crews the
first one analyzing and classifying
every for every container the evidence
chain into malicious or anomalous
anomalous could be coming as a config
errors or malicious as a result of a
thread actor the second crew then
correlate these findings of individual
containers to other containers across
the whole workloads and cluster and
finally the third crew attempts to
classify these malicious evidences into
the Kubernetes threat matrix again all
that feeds back into the chain and this
loop keeps on running until the crew
decides that the whole event is benign
or generates um an incident if it is
malicious in any way let's quickly take
a look at how this would work in action
so we are in our agentic UI uh
everything here is generated by agents
including the visualizations and nothing
is static like
dashboards so we're looking at the
vulnerability prioritization first as we
can see the funnel has reduced from 700
vulnerabilities down to three which are
active in runtime and u we can take a
look at one of the container reports
that have been generated for the first
workload in a
second and we see in the report
generated uh the asset information uh
the summary and what vulnerabilities
need to be action along with the risk
assessment that there is a privilege
assessment saying the container shares
the IPC namespace with the host uh it is
talking to critical data asset
communications are happening so the
overall risk is pretty high and we can
also talk to the agents crew asking are
there any other containers that are um
have the same vulnerabilities even if
they are not active in the runtime so
it's going to list them all down because
if I'm fixing the runtime one might as
well fix all of
them now let's have a look at the threat
hunting workflow so right now not no
incidents are there and a threat actor
tries to escalate
privileges does a container escape
breaks out steal some secrets and then
finally tries to exfiltrate data through
a reverse shell
uh this would get detected in three
different alerts one of them being the
whole incident the data excfiltration
has been detected on the container
holding Postgress and we can ask okay
what actually happened what services
parts of containers are affected it'll
list down the summary of the attack
pattern or we can add what TDPs were
used uh from the Kubernetes threat
matrix and it lists down the execution
data collection privilege escalation
steps that have been taken by the actor
we can also ask what was the data that
was excfiltrated or what SQL command was
run in the container shell to access the
data in Postgress and it'll be able to
tell that uh thanks to tetragonon again
uh and finally so what can we do about
it maybe we should not allow running
psql commands in the container shell
itself so we can human in the loop block

tetragonon to block this and kill the

these evidences can also be exported to
